text: hey everybody Thomas Joseph here now
many of you have asked me about making
bread whether that's knowing the proper
technique for kneading when to stop
kneading how to know if your bread is
fully proved well today I'm going to
show you how to make this amazing
wonderful and delicious white bread it's
pretty simple you don't need that many
ingredients and to start it all off I
have one and a half teaspoons of active
dry yeast and I'm going to add that to a
quarter of a cup of warm water now
whenever you're making bread or whenever
you're proofing yeast you really want to
use water that is at about 110 degrees
now you don't want anything that's much
higher in temperature than that because
you will kill the yeast and you don't
want anything that's cooler than that
because you really want the ease to grow
into foam so one and a half teaspoons of
sugar and the sugar is what feeds the
yeast give this a little bit of a whisk
together and now let this sit for about
five minutes until it's nice and creamy
so while that's happening I have a stand
mixer here with a dough hook attachment
and to the mixer add one in 3/4 cups of
bread flour now bread flour is very
important here because it is higher in
gluten than your all-purpose flour and
gluten gives you the structure you need
whenever you're making bread one and a
half teaspoons of kosher salt right in
with the flour and 1 cup of warm water
right into your mixer and now gently mix
this on medium speed until it comes
together the yeast mixture you can see
it's starting to foam up and that means
that the yeast is active and it's
fermenting and it's creating carbon
dioxide in that will eventually leaven
your bread now if this does not happen
that means that your yeast is way too
old yeast does expire it does die so
you're gonna have to go out and get some
fresh yeast and now add the second one
in 3/4 cups of bread flour and you add
it right here at this stage
and so now this mixes on medium speed
for about five minutes until a nice
cohesive dough forms so now it's time to
add two tablespoons of unsalted butter 1
tablespoon at a time and what's going to
happen is the dough itself might come
apart into pieces but it will come back
together and what you're listening for
this slapping and that is the butter
slapping against the sides of the bowl
and then incorporating itself back into
the dough so now I'm going to add the
remaining tablespoon of butter here and
this now needs to mix or need since
we're using the dough hook until the
dough comes back together so that'll
take a few minutes now I have to finish
the dough kneading it by hand so a
lightly floured work surface here and
what is kneading this is a great
question and a question that we get a
lot and kneading is basically the action
of folding the dough over itself and
using the palm of your hand to push it
away and what this process does is it
develops the gluten remember that's the
protein in the flour and now in the
dough itself it develops the gluten
which gives strength and structure to
the bread loaf in the end as you can see
I'm turning the dough so again it's
folding the dough over itself and then
using the palm of your hand to push it
down and away from you rotate the dough
fold it over pushing the dough away from
you and you have to do this for a few
minutes until the dough is nice and
smooth it's elastic so now this is
smooth elastic and beautiful a little
trick here this is a baker's trick to
shape this into a nice round ball just
gently rotate the dough pushing down on
it with a slight pressure but using the
tackiness of the dough and the board
itself to round out the dough into a
nice beautiful perfect ball like that so
this goes into a buttered bowl you can
turn the dough to coat it lightly in the
butter just so that the surface of the
dough doesn't dry out and now cover with
a piece of plastic wrap that's been
sprayed with nonstick cooking spray and
this needs to go in
a warm place until this has doubled in
size and this is the proofing process so
45 minutes until it's doubled in bulk
you can see it's doubled in size it's
kind of flattened out in the bowl and
what I'm going to do on a lightly
floured surface I'm going to and lightly
floured hands gently pull the dough out
onto the board and you can see how
spongy this underside is and it's the
yeast converting all of those starches
into sugars and those sugars are
creating carbon dioxide which gives the
bread its structure its strength and
also a nice Airy texture so I'm going to
Pat this out into a 7-inch square you
can see it's very tender it's not
resistant and that's a way of telling
that you've proved your dough correctly
so now take the top of the dough and
fold it down two-thirds of the way down
the bread so now I'm going to fold the
bottom up until it hits the edge here
and what you're going to do to seal this
this fold is with well floured fingers
give the dough a little bit of a pinch
so I'm kind of like tucking it under and
pinching just to seal this all together
and so now I'm going to gently turn this
dough up so that the seam is in the
center fold in the sides you can kind of
give them a little bit of a pinch here
so I have a well-buttered
eight-and-a-half by four and a half inch
loaf pan here make sure it's evenly
buttered so that this bread doesn't
stick so now gently invert this into the
pan you can push it down into the sides
of the pan here and now this goes back
into a warm place and it has to double
in size about 45 to 60 minutes so this
has been a little bit longer than 45
minutes now the dough has doubled in
size you can see that it's nicely kind
of crowning up in the pan and this goes
into the preheated 425 degrees oven for
about 15 minutes and then you're going
to reduce the temperature down to 375
degrees for about 40 to 45 minutes more
a good way to check to make sure that
the inside of the bread is done is
use an instant-read digital thermometer
insert it into the side of the loaf and
it should read 190 degrees and that's
how you know the interior of the bread
is cooked this goes right into the oven
I can't wait to show you what it looks
like when it comes out so our wonderful
beautiful loaf is right out of the oven
and what you have to do is you have to
remove it from the pan so that the
bottom doesn't steam now be careful this
is hot but if you can do it quickly and
now while it's still warm take some
softened butter and a soft bristled
brush here and gently brush on the top
of the loaf and that gives a wonderful
shine and golden color to your amazing
white bread
here just the top and now let this cool
completely before slicing our white
bread is ready to slice it has a really
nice crust but a very soft interior this
is perfect for sandwiches peanut butter
and jelly
now you have the recipe to make white
bread at home you can see how easy it is
it's just a little practice that's all
it takes
give it a try
